prs.title: op-service: add the txinclude and accounting packages
prs.truncated_body:
Commit message has more details.

# Burst Metrics
`NAT_INTEROP_LOADTEST_BUDGET=2`

Burst test is now able to sustain load without crashing to zero:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1e1c8a75-dd61-4f8d-8b00-5fcc4cb1963b)

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/136a03a0-0665-41ad-8e52-b1775a004c1e)

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b751e446

commits.message:
op-service: add the txinclude and accounting packages

and use them in the interop load test.

# Problem

The interop load test needs to spam a lot of transactions. Some of those
transactions may fail due to transient errors. The load test must be able
to recover from such errors and continue spamming.

The `op-service/txmgr` package provides the kind of transaction inclusion
guarantees that load tests need. Unfortunately, it relies on the elegant
but extensive `ETHBackend` interface, which is incompatible with the
`apis.EthAPI` preferred by the `op-devstack`.

We need a simple API that can provide the same (or better) inclusion
guarantees as `txmgr.*SimpleTxManager.Send`. As a bonus, a simple API would
also compose with `txplan.Option` patterns beginning to proliferate
throughout the monorepo.

# Solution

The `txinclude` package, supported by the `accounting` package, provides
this simple API. It is not yet as featureful as `txmgr`, but it should
be easy to fill in the missing pieces when needs arise. Its core interface

```
Include(context.Context, types.TxData) error
```

is simple to implement and has minimal dependencies.

## Load test changes

The load test now implements `txinclude`'s simple metrics interface with
a few lines of code, providing deeper insights into transaction submission
behaviors than was previously practical.

# Future Work

## Deeper `txplan` Integration

As far as I can tell, a `WithIncluder` `txplan.Option` would require
something like this:

```go
// WithIncluder may cause a goroutine leak if Included is never evaluated.
func WithIncluder(includer txinclude.Includer) txplan.Option {
	return func(tx *PlannedTx) {
		includedCh := make(chan *txinclude.IncludedTx)
		errCh := make(chan error)

		tx.Submitted.DependOn(&tx.Unsigned)
		tx.Submitted.Fn(func(ctx context.Context) (struct{}, error) {
			go func() {
				included, err := includer.Include(ctx, tx.Unsigned.Value())
				errCh <- err
				includedCh <- included
			}()
			return struct{}{}, nil
		})

		// NOTE: tx.Included needs to return *txinclude.IncludedTx since the
		// transaction may be modified by the includer before it is sent
		// (e.g., incrementing the nonce).
		tx.Included.DependOn(&tx.Submitted)
		tx.Included.Fn(func(_ context.Context) (*txinclude.IncludedTx, error) {
			return <-includedCh, <-errCh
		})
	}
```

This is a suboptimal solution. A proper `txplan`<>`txinclude` integration
shouldn't be too challenging (it will likely mean removing the
`PlannedTx.Submitted` field), but it is hairy enough to be left to another
PR.

## Implement Missing `txmgr` Features

Three features that likely belong in the `Persistent` `Includer`
implementation are fee bumps, per-transaction budgeting, and ordering
guarantees.

Fee bumps would probably require extending the `EL` interface to include
`EstimateGas`. Per-transaction budgeting could be implemented by returning
an error if `EstimateGas` goes beyond what a single transaction should
spend on gas.

Ordering guarantees could be implemented by extending the `Includer`
interface in a backward-compatible way:

```go
// Include includes a transaction in a blockchain.
// tx and others are guaranteed to be included in the order they
// are listed by the caller.
Include(ctx context.Context, tx, others ...tx.Data) (*IncludedTx, error)
```

## Merge `EthAPI` and `ETHBackend`

Currently, the codebase is bifurcated into code that speaks `EthAPI` and code
that speaks variations of `txmgr.ETHBackend` (see the multiple `WaitForBlock`
implementations). Because the `txinclude.EL` interface supports both, this is
a first step towards a fuller solution that pays off the tech debt entirely.

prs.truncated_body:
# Description

This PR introduces VeBlop span rotation.

Major changes:
* Today, each span is deterministically written to a contract for future blocks. After VeBlop, the span will be proactively retrieved from heimdall when the current block producer fails to deliver new blocks within a certain time range, which is currently set at 4s. 
* Remove span commit and validator set info in header

prs.title: StarkNet L1 Bitcoin Depositor Deployment
prs.truncated_body:
## Overview

This PR implements the StarkNet L1 Bitcoin Depositor contract, enabling direct Bitcoin-to-StarkNet bridging through the tBTC v2 system. Users can now mint tBTC directly on StarkNet without needing to interact with Ethereum L1.

## Implementation Details

### Contracts
- **StarkNetBitcoinDepositor**: L1 depositor contract that integrates with StarkGate bridge
- Inherits from `A

commits.message:
feat(starknet): update StarkNetBitcoinDepositor and deployment artifacts

- Added new tBTC bridging functionality to StarkNetBitcoinDepositor, including fee estimation and event emissions for bridging operations.
- Removed unused variables and events related to L1→L2 message fees and fee buffers to streamline the contract.
- Updated deployment artifacts for Sepolia with the latest contract address and transaction hash.
- Enhanced deployment script for StarkNet with updated StarkGate bridge address for Sepolia.
- Improved event logging for better tracking of bridging transactions.

StarkNet Mainnet Crosschain Deployment and Update of the configuration and deployment scripts

- Modified hardhat.config.ts to use environment variables for Sepolia and Mainnet API URLs and account private keys.
- Added new deployment scripts for setting reimbursement fee and estimating gas costs.
- Introduced dry-run deployment script for testing deployment parameters without executing transactions.
- Updated deployment artifacts for StarkNetBitcoinDepositor with new addresses and transaction hashes.
- Enhanced contract interfaces and internal functions for better readability and consistency.
- Added new JSON configuration for OpenZeppelin deployment on Mainnet.

prs.title: Add Vortex contract
prs.truncated_body:
## Description

Closes: *#XXXX*

The purpose of Vortex is to allow Hydro to create concentrated liquidity positions of ATOM vs potentially volatile tokens while minimizing risk to Hydro’s ATOM principal. It does this by creating concentrated liquidity positions where the other side of the position acts as collateral to secure the ATOM side.
More description on: [vortex liquidity collateral sy

commits.message: add rough draft of position creation
rough draft of creating position and imported Osmosis testing stuff
added script to simulate CL positions
Contract is able to enter, query and withdraw cl position, tested with OsmosisTestApp
Merge branch 'liquid-collateral' of https://github.com/informalsystems/hydro into liquid-collateral
refactored creating position and liquidate method with reply

successfully tested whole happy path:
- contract enters position
- a swap happens which causes principal token amount to reach zero in pool
- liquidation is executed by a liquidator who provides principal tokens to contract
-liquidator is given appropriate amount of counterparty token
- contract is left with principal token amount and amount of counterparty token earned from rewards

- only one position can be created
- liquidity_shares fetched from contract state
- liquidity_shares updated after (partial) liquidation

implemented end of round endpoint:
- makes sure round is ended
- pulls position
- if principal amount is >= of initial principal amount
  - reserves all wobble to the owner
  - reserve initial principal amount to hydro
  - reserve the rest of atom to the owner
-else:
 - kick-offs the auction (which is not yet implemented)

calculate optimal upper range and counterparty amount given:
- price ratio
- principal amount
- liquidation bonus
- lower tick
(initial logic)

- changed hydro to "principal_funds_owner"
- owner is now "project_owner" and is optional
- tokens are immediatelly distributed instead of reservations
- track principal_to_replenish instead of initial_principal_amount because of partial liquidations followed up with end round

- changed inserting bids logic:
 - added amount validation constraints
 - added logic for sorting bids so we always know which one is the worst
 - defend against inserting huge amount of bids by replacing bids once amount to replenish is deposited.
 - change in calculating position parameters logic

- allow partial fulfill of the bids
- do not allow withdraw during the auction
- test  resolving auction

- all bids are stored with status codes
- sorted bits are storing only bids which will be processed in resoving auction
- auction can be resolved even though not all amount is replenished

- fetch all rewards (spread and incentives):
- rewards are fetched automatically in case contract pulls out the whole position
- addes queries before liquidation which makes sure contract knows if there are rewards
- and in the reply - transfer all potential rewards to the principal funds owner

- principal and counterparty are now dynamically fetched from position
- new boolean field "principal_first" added in order for contract to be aware if the principal token is at the position "0" or "1"
- if set to "true" - it's in the position "0" (first)
- create position: token min amounts dynamically passed regarding principal token position in pool

- liquidity parsed such that it can either contain dot or not
- calculation of price based on the tick

- added partial liquidation test
- contract querying position for saving liquidity_shares instead of manually computing
- round big method refactoring
different strategies for upper tick and counterparty calculations
print principal token amount and liquidation bonus input amounts in test
calc final amount at lower tick
